name: Yemen
currentCrisisSummary:
Yemen endures one of the world's most severe humanitarian catastrophes, driven by a fragmented **proxy war** over state control and its **strategic position** on a key **global trade route**. The conflict involves multiple actors: the Iran-aligned **Houthi movement**, a **Saudi-led coalition** (backed by **Western arms/intelligence**) supporting the internationally recognised government, the **UAE-backed secessionist Southern Transitional Council (STC)**, and **Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP)**.

This multi-sided war, waged through **blockades**, **sieges**, and attacks on infrastructure, has deliberately crippled the nation. Violence and **externally imposed restrictions** have devastated the economy, wrecked public services, and produced **catastrophic hunger and disease**. The crisis is actively sustained by **international arms flows**, **regional rivalries** (Saudi/Iran, Saudi/UAE), and **global economic interests**.

imperialRoot.imperialPower: Britain & Ottoman Empire (Aden 1839-1967; Ottoman presence in the north until 1918)
imperialRoot.legacy:
The crisis draws on deep **colonial-era divisions**. **British control** (south) alongside **Ottoman administration** (north) produced distinct legacies. Britain's **protectorates** and **indirect rule** hindered unity, leaving a **governance vacuum** and fostering **southern identity** later mobilised by secessionists.

These **colonial partitions**, plus later **Cold War geopolitics**, created fault-lines exploited by elites and **foreign powers**, contributing to cycles of conflict and **external intervention**.

historicalContext.title: Geopolitical Chokepoint and Global Trade
historicalContext.description: Yemen's geography astride the **Bab-el-Mandeb strait**, a vital **chokepoint** for **global trade**, makes it a theatre for **strategic competition**. **Regional powers** (Saudi Arabia, Iran, UAE) and global actors seek influence. Control of **maritime access** is a persistent objective for **external actors**.

historicalContext.title: Internal Fragmentation: STC and Southern Secessionism
historicalContext.description: The anti-Houthi bloc is deeply divided. The **Southern Transitional Council (STC)**, primarily backed by the **UAE**, seeks independence for South Yemen. The STC frequently clashes with the **Saudi-backed** internationally recognised government forces, despite both nominally opposing the Houthis. This **internal conflict**, driven by secessionist goals and **Saudi-UAE rivalry**, further fragments the state.

historicalContext.title: Neoliberal Reforms and the Roots of Rebellion
historicalContext.description: Post-unification, Yemen faced **IMF/World Bank-led Structural Adjustment Programmes (SAPs)**. These **neoliberal 'reforms'** mandated lifting subsidies, **privatisation**, and severe **austerity**. Hardship affected marginalised regions, feeding grievances of southern secessionists and the northern **Houthi rebellion**. The Houthi rise was partly a revolt against **corruption** from this **Western-backed economic model**.

historicalContext.title: The War on Terror: AQAP and US Intervention
historicalContext.description: Yemen has long been a key front in the US '**Global War on Terror**'. **Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP)** exploited state weakness to establish a presence. The US conducted extensive **drone strikes** and **special forces operations** against AQAP, often with the complicity of the Saleh regime, which also used US aid against domestic rivals like the **Houthis**. This **external security framework** complicated internal dynamics and contributed to radicalisation.

historicalContext.title: Proxy War and Western Complicity
historicalContext.description: The current war escalated with the 2015 **Saudi-led coalition intervention**. This intervention received crucial **direct military and intelligence support** from the **US and UK** (refuelling, targeting), alongside massive **arms transfers**. This **Western complicity** enabled the coalition's devastating bombing campaign and naval blockade, key drivers of the humanitarian catastrophe.

historicalContext.title: International Law and Accountability
historicalContext.description: Extensive documentation by UN bodies and human rights organisations has recorded **war crimes** and **crimes against humanity** committed by all parties (Houthis, Saudi-led coalition, STC forces, AQAP). The **blockade-induced starvation**, **indiscriminate bombing campaigns**, and **targeting of civilian infrastructure** violate international humanitarian law. Despite formal **accountability** mechanisms, **impunity** persists due to geopolitical interference. The **UN Security Council** remains divided, preventing referral to the **ICC**. **Arms suppliers** (US, UK, France etc.) continue to enable violations with **impunity**, highlighting the **selective application** of international law.

humanitarianImpact.title: Casualties
humanitarianImpact.description: Hundreds of thousands killed (est. 377k by late 2021) directly by fighting or indirectly through **conflict-induced starvation and disease**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Affected Population
humanitarianImpact.description: Roughly 19.5 million require aid due to the systematic destruction caused by warring parties and their **international backers**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Food Insecurity
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 17 million face acute hunger from **blockades**, attacks on agriculture, and **economic collapse caused by the war**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Displacement
humanitarianImpact.description: Around 4.5 million internally displaced by bombing, fighting, and **climate shocks exacerbated by state failure**.

timeline.event: **British seize Aden**: The British Empire captures the port of Aden, beginning a prolonged colonial presence in southern Yemen that would shape later regional divisions.
**Unification**: North (Yemen Arab Republic) and South (People's Democratic Republic of Yemen) formally unite. Structural economic and political differences produce long-standing grievances.

**Civil War & Neoliberal Riots**: A short but bitter civil war deepens southern grievances. The conflict is exacerbated by widespread popular anger against IMF-mandated austerity measures imposed after unification.

**"War on Terror", AQAP & Houthi Uprising**: The US expands counter-terror operations (drone strikes) against **AQAP**. The Saleh regime uses US military aid to suppress domestic opponents, particularly the nascent Houthi rebellion.

**Houthi Advance & Coalition Intervention**: Houthi forces seize Sana'a. A **Saudi-led coalition** (inc. UAE), backed by **US/UK intelligence and logistics**, launches an air/naval campaign and enforces blockades, precipitating the humanitarian catastrophe.
**STC Formation**: The **UAE-backed Southern Transitional Council (STC)** is formed, demanding independence for the South and adding another layer of conflict within the anti-Houthi bloc.
**Protracted Humanitarian Catastrophe**: Years of siege, economic collapse, aid obstruction, and attacks on infrastructure create one of the worldâ€™s worst humanitarian emergencies.

donate.description: Offers critical support, such as food packs, clean water, and healthcare, to Yemenis suffering from the protracted conflict, blockade, and resulting hunger crisis.
Provides life-saving food, child protection services, and cash assistance to families who have lost everything in the ongoing war.
A Yemeni-led diaspora organisation providing direct aid, cash assistance and advocacy for reconstruction and peace.

advocacy.title: End Blockades and Sieges
advocacy.description: Demand an immediate end to blockades and sieges and insist on unimpeded, independent humanitarian access to all civilians.

advocacy.title: Suspend Arms Transfers
advocacy.description: Call on Western and regional governments to suspend **all arms transfers** (to Saudi Arabia, UAE, Iran, etc.) that enable indiscriminate attacks and violations of international law.

advocacy.title: Support Yemeni-Led Peace
advocacy.description: Support Yemeni-led peace initiatives that address **internal fragmentation** (North/South, STC) and ensure that any diplomatic settlement protects civilians and restores services.

advocacy.title: Demand Accountability
advocacy.description: Push for independent investigations into alleged war crimes by **all parties** and for accountability mechanisms that centre victims' rights and reparations.

reading.title: *Destroying Yemen: What Chaos in Arabia Tells Us about the World*
reading.description: Isa Blumi's critical history linking Yemen's modern conflicts to longer legacies of imperial intervention and regional power struggles.

reading.title: *Yemen in Crisis: Autocracy, Neo-Liberalism and the Disintegration of a State*
reading.description: Helen Lackner provides a detailed study of the political, social, and economic drivers, including neoliberal policies, that led to Yemen's current war.

reading.title: *Yemen Endures: Civil War, Saudi Adventurism and the Future of Arabia*
reading.description: Edited by Ginny Hill, et al. This collection analyses governance failures, the impact of neoliberalism, and regional interventions contributing to state collapse.
